text: no :d
anyone know good json to pojo converter?

json usually isn’t descriptive enough to make a pojo so you end up with pojo’s that are wrong. What you really want is a json schema of which you can more easily generate pojo’s in multiple languages. As you usually do not need to create pojo’s in multiple languages you’ll probably save yourself some time by just writing the pojo’s by hand
<@U0ESBF4AV> <http://www.jsonschema2pojo.org/>

attachments.title: jsonschema2pojo
attachments.text: Generate Plain Old Java Objects from JSON or JSON-Schema.

text: just change it to JSON from JSON schema and it's good to go
<@U39P7U6EP> tried that one,  but the gson one generated exposed annotation too which I don't need :smile:
That's what I use for JSON to POJO but then usually have to tweak things a little bit.
<@U055GGAHS> Slowly I think that's the better choice :smile:
Started making the switch to using autovalue, so now I just do things by hand.
<@U0ESBF4AV> I would honestly just stop using gson
alternates like logan square offer vastly better performance on mobile (and desktop) and often require less work to get working properly
<@U05473HHT> Can you post some good starting links for autovalue.
what json parser are you using usually? Jackson?
I also mostly ( always :P) use jsonschema2Pojo
<@U3DCPPVCP> <https://github.com/google/auto/blob/master/value/userguide/index.md>

attachments.text: auto - A collection of source code generators for Java.

text: Oh used logansquare too for my hobby project in the past
is it stable?
yeah
logansquare generated source is extremely easy to read (it’s just manual streaming json parsing)
<@U3DCPPVCP> I always refer to the documentation itself that <@U055GGAHS> posted above.
Just check and it's 1.3.6, seems stable
we use auto and logansquare in production, no problems with either
pretty sure a *lot* of other people are too
they are both very simple libs
<@U05473HHT> is autovalue playing nice with gson? or do you need any adapter?
<@U055GGAHS> do I need additional adapter?
<@U05473HHT> <@U055GGAHS> I tried reading documentation and it went over my head, that's why I asked for beginner posts :stuck_out_tongue:. It was a long time ago though, so I'll try again.

we have internal auto value objects that we map our json objects to but alternate tools like this exist

<https://github.com/yongjhih/AutoJson>
I can’t comment on how well that works though
I see, let's just use logansquare only for now
Thanks <@U055GGAHS> :taco:

our reasoning is our auto value models represented our internal database while logan square represented our API and we didn’t want our database to be locked into whatever the API ends up needing to do in the future
<@U0ESBF4AV> I use <https://github.com/rharter/auto-value-gson> for Gson support. It automatically creates my TypeAdapter.

attachments.title: rharter/auto-value-gson
attachments.text: auto-value-gson - AutoValue Extension to add Gson De/Serializer support

text: Thanks <@U05473HHT> :taco:

Started with autovalue last week for one of our model objects and I wrote 75% less code than what was originally there. I have the same functionality and even a little bit more thanks to auto-value-gson creating the TypeAdapter automatically.

the benchmarks on logansquare github feel so unreal :stuck_out_tongue:
Any ideas what makes it so fast?
logan writes streaming json parsing code and maps directly to object members
because it’s generated code it writes code exactly for parsing each model compared to something like gson which has to generically map json to a model
I recommend you create your logan model and build your app, you can then go to `build/generated/source/apt/…` and check the generated source for your model
it’ll be a class called `YourModelName$$JsonObjectMapper`
I’ll do that.
I read a discussion about code generation on moshi github repo
the discussion seemed to refute this method to have any benefit which is what confuses me
i think it was this one: <https://github.com/square/moshi/issues/64>

attachments.title: How about a JSON parser code generator on top of Moshi? · Issue #64 · square/moshi · GitHub
attachments.text: Some people are very concerned about speed... especially when it comes to JSON parsing and reflection. So my question would be: Does it make sense for you guys to add a parser generator on top (som...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: How about a JSON parser code generator on top of Moshi? · Issue #64 · square/moshi

text: <@U0ESBF4AV> I tend to generate the pojo for GSON, and then I just go at it with find+replace and replace the annotations from `@SerializedName` to `@JsonField(name=" ")` and add `@JsonObject` and use LoganSquare
<@U1E6BDDEE> I don't like Moshi API at all, I like LoganSquare it just generates things and works 100%
moshi seems fine if you have a reason to use it
as for that thread <@U1E6BDDEE> that doesn’t say anything negative about code generation
just simply in the context of moshi they aren’t interested in adding it and indirectly determined it would likely be an unproductive avenue for their library
Well, maybe i didn't understand the discussion well :stuck_out_tongue:  Thanks for clarifying :taco:
As for having a reason to use moshi, what would be a valid reason? Is there something special it provides?
<@U055GGAHS> :taco:
it provides gson style functionality and seems to provide greater performance
their custom type adapters example for instance would be a reason to use it over logan square
instead of using a type adapter, we read our models with logan square then postprocess them while a type adapter is really a preprocessor
neither approach is wrong but one or the other is likely better for your app
logansquare does have a higher method count though
maybe 900 difference is not that significant though
if it gives you development convenience and speed
<@U1E6BDDEE> is method count really such a problem? I mean, I'd assume the Multidex Support Library solves most issues with 64k+
<@U3L2VAK2T|jonathanfk> has joined the channel
<@U39P7U6EP> if you don't like spending 2.5 mins per build yeah
<@U08GFT5V5> oh so that's why my projects with 60k methods take 4 minutes, lol
not really, multidexin’ here, ranging from 15 sec to 2m15sec lately
and that’s on a MBA
